abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>This study presents <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content> barcode records for 4118 specimens representing 561 species of bees belonging to the six families of <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>poidea (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>ndrenidae, <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>pidae, <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">C</jats:styled-content>olletidae, <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">H</jats:styled-content>alictidae, <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">M</jats:styled-content>egachilidae and <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">M</jats:styled-content>elittidae) found in <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">C</jats:styled-content>entral <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">E</jats:styled-content>urope. These records provide fully compliant barcode sequences for 503 of the 571 bee species in the <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">G</jats:styled-content>erman fauna and partial sequences for 43 more. The barcode results are largely congruent with traditional taxonomy as only five closely allied pairs of species could not be discriminated by barcodes. As well, 90% of the species possessed sufficiently deep sequence divergence to be assigned to a different <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">B</jats:styled-content>arcode <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">I</jats:styled-content>ndex <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">N</jats:styled-content>umber (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">BIN</jats:styled-content>). In fact, 56 species (11%) were assigned to two or more <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">BIN</jats:styled-content>s reflecting the high levels of intraspecific divergence among their component specimens. Fifty other species (9.7%) shared the same <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">B</jats:styled-content>arcode <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">I</jats:styled-content>ndex <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">N</jats:styled-content>umber with one or more species, but most of these species belonged to a distinct barcode cluster within a particular <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">BIN</jats:styled-content>. The barcode data contributed to clarifying the status of nearly half the examined taxonomically problematic species of bees in the <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">G</jats:styled-content>erman fauna. Based on these results, the role of <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content> barcoding as a tool for current and future taxonomic work is discussed.</jats:p>
title: DNA barcoding largely supports 250 years of classical taxonomy: identifications for Central European bees (Hymenoptera, Apoidea partim)
